madhumandavarasāmadānaṃ.meaning_2: offering of sweet, mellow nectar; offering of delicious, honey-like juice; (contextual) offering of a sweet, intoxicating liquid (e.g. honey-wine or juice)
madhumandavarasāmadānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1] This is a compound combining 'madhu' (honey/sweet), 'manda' (charming/sweet/tender), 'rasa' (juice/nectar/taste), 'mada' (intoxication/pleasure), and 'dāna' (offering/gift) to mean the offering of a sweet, intoxicating nectar or juice. Contextually, it may refer to the ritual or act of making such an offering in a religious or ceremonial setting.

akukkuṭajātaṃ.meaning_2: type of chicken; kind of cock; species of rooster
akukkuṭajātaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1] Compound formed from 'kukkuṭa' (cock, chicken) and 'jāta' (type, kind, class). Refers to a category or species of chicken/rooster. The acc. sg. form indicates it is being used as the grammatical object or in relation to something.

abhumme.meaning_2: oh no!; oh dear!; alas!; woe is me!; damn!
abhumme.comment: [openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1] Contextually, 'abhumme' expresses a strong exclamation of horror or distress, matching the English translation 'Woe is me!'. This is an indeclinable exclamatory form related to 'abhuṃ', with the ending -e indicating a possible vocative/exclamatory usage.
abhumme.translation_1: ‘Woe is me! It’s a damn goblin!’

kuñjararāhulasassataloko.meaning_2: the world made eternal by the elephant-like Rāhula; the world illuminated/characterized by the perpetual (sassata) elephant (kuñjara) Rāhula
kuñjararāhulasassataloko.comment: [openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1] This is a compound word formed from kuñjara (elephant), rāhula (proper name), sassata (eternal), and loka (world). The compound appears to refer to a world associated with, sanctified by, or characterized as eternal by Rāhula with elephant-like qualities. The compound is an example of a descriptive bahubbīhi or karmadhāraya.

bhaddālināmo.meaning_2: named Bhaddāli; a monk called Bhaddāli
bhaddālināmo.comment: [openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1] This is a compound personal name of a monk, formed from 'bhaddāli' (a proper name) and 'nāma' (called, named), indicating someone named Bhaddāli.

khuddadijāthasahampatiyācaṃ.meaning_2: the request/begging of Khuddadija, Atha, and Sahampati; petition of Khuddadija, Atha, and Sahampati
khuddadijāthasahampatiyācaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1] This is a sandhi compound consisting of five components: khudda (small), dija (bird, Brahman, or tooth—likely bird here), atha (then/also), sahampati (the Brahma), and yāca (a request/begged item). The compound likely refers to the petition or request made by Khuddadija, Atha, and Sahampati together, suggesting a scene where these figures jointly make a request.

nāḷakaraññikiṭāgirināmo.meaning_2: called Nāḷaka-aranna-Kiṭāgiri; so called Nāḷaka forest and Kiṭāgiri; named Nāḷaka-aranna and Kiṭāgiri
nāḷakaraññikiṭāgirināmo.comment: [openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1] This is a compound place name consisting of 'Nāḷaka', 'arañña' (forest), and 'Kiṭāgiri', with 'nāma' (called/named) as a suffix indicating naming. Used to indicate a place known as Nāḷaka-aranna and Kiṭāgiri.

aparise.meaning_2: not a group; not an assembly; not a gathering
aparise.comment: [openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1] This appears to be a negative formation from 'parisā' (assembly, group) using the 'na' negative prefix, so it means the absence of a group or assembly. Follows standard compound and negation formation.

abhide.comment: [openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1] Appears to be a rare or context-specific indeclinable, perhaps a variant or dialectal form; possibly meaning 'in front (of)' or 'before'. If more context or sentence were provided, the nuance could be clarified.

puṇḍarīaggisahakathināmo.meaning_2: called having a discussion with the fire of Puṇḍarī; named as the one having conversation with Puṇḍarī-fire
puṇḍarīaggisahakathināmo.comment: [openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1] This is a multi-term compound adjective formed from puṇḍarī (a proper noun or feminine form possibly referring to a person, location, or concept in the text), aggi (fire), saha (with/together), kathī (discourse/discussing), and nāma (called/named). The word refers to something or someone designated by having a discussion with the 'Puṇḍarī-fire' or 'fire of Puṇḍarī'. The context would clarify whether this is a formal name or an epithet applied in a narrative. There is no root, as it is a nominal compound.

dhānañjāni.meaning_2: name of a kind of ascetic's bark garment; name of a person (as found in some texts)
dhānañjāni.comment: [openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1] This is a compound word, likely referring to either a garment made from the bark of the dhānañjāni tree, or as a proper name; compounded from dhāna (placing, putting) + ja (born, produced) + jāni (wife or seizure, but often the taddhita form as in a female being, hence also a name). Usage and nuance can depend on the vinaya or narrative context.

kintisāmasunakkhattaṃ.meaning_2: name of a monk; lit. why-so-brown-auspicious-occasion
kintisāmasunakkhattaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1] This appears to be a compound personal name, combining 'kiṃ' (what?/why?), 'ti' (quot. particle), 'sāma' (brown), and 'sunakkhatta' (auspicious occasion or the proper name Sunakkhatta). The name likely refers to someone being called 'why-so-brown Sunakkhatta', perhaps humorously or as a pejorative. Without a sentence context, the meaning remains primarily as a proper noun.

sappāyagaṇagopakamahāpuṇṇacūḷapuṇṇañcāti.meaning_2: the [discourse/section/group] on beneficial groups, guardians, Mahāpuṇṇa and Cūḷapuṇṇa; collection relating to sappāya-groups, gopaka, Mahāpuṇṇa and Cūḷapuṇṇa
sappāyagaṇagopakamahāpuṇṇacūḷapuṇṇañcāti.comment: [openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1] This is a long compound word, neuter in compound construction, combining the names of well-known discourses or groupings (sappāya-gaṇa, gopaka, Mahāpuṇṇa and Cūḷapuṇṇa). In context, likely refers to a collection or summary that includes all these topics.

athassumegho.meaning_2: Assumegha; name of a privately awakened Buddha; lit. cloud of tears
athassumegho.comment: [openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1] The word represents the proper noun Assumegha, the name of a paccekabuddha mentioned in the context. It is a compound of 'assu' (tears) and 'megha' (cloud).

odhastaitipadavibhāgo.comment: [openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1] This compound refers specifically to the parsing or grammatical analysis (padavibhāga) of the word ‘odhastāti’ or ‘odhasta iti’. It's a technical term used in grammatical or commentarial context to designate the breakdown of the compound or phrase.

anupādasodhanaporisadhammo.meaning_2: the characteristic of purifying the succession (of the mind or actions) found among true men; the cleansing quality of sequentially purifying qualities in a person
anupādasodhanaporisadhammo.comment: [openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1] This is a compound masculine noun combining 'anupāda' (succession, sequence), 'sodhana' (cleansing, purifying) as an adjectival compound, and 'porisadhamma' (characteristics/qualities of a person), forming a technical term reminiscent of lists in Sappurisasutta (MN 113); it refers to the specific noble quality of purifying each step or stage, especially as possessed by a 'true man'.

sevitabbabahudhātuvibhatti.meaning_2: declension or inflection with many elements or types which should be practised/observed/served; inflection of the 'sevitabba' type (should be associated with/practised) for verbs with many stems/elements
sevitabbabahudhātuvibhatti.comment: [openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1] This is a technical grammatical term referring to the inflection or declension (vibhatti) of potential participles like 'sevitabba' in verbs (or stems) with multiple elements (bahudhātu), i.e., polystematic verbs. Usage is typically in traditional grammatical texts to illustrate forms or patterns.

kittināmacattārīsena.meaning_2: forty famous names; forty celebrated names
kittināmacattārīsena.comment: [openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1] This compound forms a collective neuter noun referencing a group of forty famous names. Based on the related entries for 'kitti', 'nāma', and 'cattārīsa', all three combine into a single descriptive term, best rendered as 'forty famous names' within the context.

tathārūpāhi.meaning_2: such; of such kind; of such quality; so formed; suitable; appropriate; fitting
tathārūpāhi.comment: [openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1] Contextually, the word describes speech or words of such quality—those that are fitting, agreeable, or of that character as described in the prior list of positive attributes.
tathārūpāhi.example_1: tamenaṃ hatthidamako yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇasukhā pemanīyā hadayaṅgamā porī bahujanakantā bahujanamanāpā tathārūpāhi vācāhi samudācarati.
tathārūpāhi.translation_1: He spoke in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.
tathārūpāhi.example_2: yato kho, aggivessana, āraññako nāgo hatthidamakassa yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇasukhā pemanīyā hadayaṅgamā porī bahujanakantā bahujanamanāpā tathārūpāhi vācāhi samudācariyamāno sussūsati, sotaṃ odahati, aññā cittaṃ upaṭṭhāpeti;
tathārūpāhi.translation_2: Spoken to in such a way by the elephant trainer, the wild elephant wanted to listen. It actively listened and tried to understand.

khārodikā.comment: [openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1] A feminine noun referring to a type of pickle or brined vegetable; its formation is from 'khāro' (alkali, brine) with the taddhita suffix 'dika' and the feminine ending 'ā'. Common in Buddhist Vinaya context for food items offered to monks.

amāhaṃiti.comment: [openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1] The word is an indeclinable negative expression, 'not I', likely used for personal negation or emphasis of absence of self. 'Māhaṃ' is a rarely used pronoun for 'I'; 'a-' is the negative prefix.

piḷandhanavikatiyā.meaning_2: type of ornament; kind of jewellery; form of adornment
piḷandhanavikatiyā.comment: [openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1] In context, refers to the various forms or types of ornaments (bracelet, earrings, etc.) the gold can be fashioned into after being refined. This is a compound: piḷandhana (ornament, jewellery) + vikati (form, type, modification, creation).
piḷandhanavikatiyā.example_1: seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, dakkho suvaṇṇakāro vā suvaṇṇakārantevāsī vā ukkaṃ bandheyya, ukkaṃ bandhitvā ukkāmukhaṃ ālimpeyya, ukkāmukhaṃ ālimpetvā saṇḍāsena jātarūpaṃ gahetvā ukkāmukhe pakkhipeyya, tamenaṃ kālena kālaṃ abhidhameyya, kālena kālaṃ udakena paripphoseyya, kālena kālaṃ ajjhupekkheyya, taṃ hoti jātarūpaṃ sudhantaṃ niddhantaṃ nīhaṭaṃ ninnītakasāvaṃ mudu ca kammaññañca pabhassarañca, yassā yassā ca piḷandhanavikatiyā ākaṅkhati—yadi paṭṭikāya yadi kuṇḍalāya yadi gīveyyakāya yadi suvaṇṇamālāya tañcassa atthaṃ anubhoti;
piḷandhanavikatiyā.translation_1: It’s like when a deft goldsmith or a goldsmith’s apprentice prepares a forge, fires the crucible, picks up some native gold with tongs and puts it in the crucible. From time to time they fan it, from time to time they sprinkle water on it, and from time to time they just watch over it. That native gold becomes pliable, workable, and radiant, not brittle, and is ready to be worked. Then the goldsmith can successfully create any kind of ornament they want, whether a bracelet, earrings, a necklace, or a golden garland.

abhivādanapaccuṭṭhānaañjalikamma.meaning_2: paying respect by bowing, rising from one's seat and saluting with joined palms; formal acts of veneration
abhivādanapaccuṭṭhānaañjalikamma.comment: [openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1] This is a compound neuter noun formed from three ritual action nouns: abhivādana (bowing/paying respect), paccuṭṭhāna (standing/rising in respect), and añjalikamma (joining palms in salutation). It denotes the collection of these respectful salutations, especially as a formal sequence or as acts of devotion in Buddhist contexts.

abhivādanapaccuṭṭhānaañjalikammasāmīcika.meaning_2: bowing down, rising from one's seat, respectful salutation, respectful conduct, (providing) robes, alms food, housing; all these together as duties or supports
abhivādanapaccuṭṭhānaañjalikammasāmīcika.family_compound: abhivādana paccuṭṭhāna añjalikamma sāmīcikamma cīvara piṇḍapāta senāsana gila
abhivādanapaccuṭṭhānaañjalikammasāmīcika.construction: abhivādana + paccuṭṭhāna + añjalikamma + sāmīcikamma + cīvara + piṇḍapāta + senāsana + gila
abhivādanapaccuṭṭhānaañjalikammasāmīcika.comment: [openrouter: openai/gpt-4.1] This very long compound refers collectively to both forms of respect (salutation, rising, gestures, proper conduct) and offerings (robes, alms food, dwellings) and perhaps even their consumption or acceptance (gila), likely expressing the whole set of services and duties offered, particularly in a vinaya or ritual context.
